titlestmt.titleproper: Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching (CHART) records
A Guide to the Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching (CHART) records FA422
titlestmt.author: Callie Hopkins

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-06-20 00:06:39 -0400.

did.unittitle: Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching (CHART) records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching

physdesc.extent: 22 boxes: 18 document boxes, 3 half-boxes, and 1 flat box for photos.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The RAC holds all legal title, copyright, and literary rights to the records, which are open for scholarly use.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research with select materials restricted (as noted). Brittle or damaged materials are available at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains materials related to the group Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching (CHART), a project of the Rockefeller Foundation that operated from 1983-1994. While a few documents come from as early as 1983 or as late as 1994, the bulk of the materials date between 1987 and 1993. Series 1 includes substantial correspondence from CHART director Judith Renyi to the Rockefeller Foundation, CHART site directors, and many others, as well as some additional planning materials. Major Rockefeller Foundation correspondents include Alberta Arthurs and Hugh B. Price. Series 2 contains details about potential CHART sites, the CHARTnet telecommunications network between teachers, the Africa in the U.S. Classroom project, and other reports on national education issues. This series also contains considerable information about the creation and publication of the CHART book, Fire in the Eyes of Youth, a copy of which text is in the public relations materials in box 21. Series 3 includes materials such as agendas, handouts, and transcripts from various conferences which CHART members either attended or helped to organize. Finally, series 4 houses many of CHART's public relations materials, including newspaper clippings and other media as well as formal information kits. Substantial content throughout the collection also relates to individual projects sponsored by CHART, such as Humanitas and PATHS. Overall, major topics covered include the humanities, the arts, multicultural and international education, school reform and restructuring, and the funding for such reforms.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The CHART records are arranged into the following four series: 1.Administration 2.Projects 3.Conferences and Institutes 4.Public Relations

The original arrangement of the documents was largely retained, except in cases where titles were clearly inaccurate or items clearly misfiled. The original reverse chronological order was retained at the item level (and documents were occasionally rearranged to maintain this order), but alphabetical-chronological order was imposed at the folder level.

Four sheets of photographs and one cassette tape had to be removed from the main collection for preservation. The photographs are housed in oversize box 22, while the cassette tape has been removed to Special Formats.

bioghist.head: Institutional History
bioghist.p: Collaboratives for Humanities and Arts Teaching (CHART) was initiated in 1983 by the Rockefeller Foundation, although it did not formally adopt the name CHART until 1987. CHART began in response to the 1980 Rockefeller Foundation report "The Humanities in American Life," which warned of a crisis in American humanities education, and as a way to combat the "back to basics" pedagogy that predominated at the time and left students drilling and memorizing rather than learning and exploring. While they started with the goal of improving humanities education, CHART leaders soon realized that this goal was almost impossible to achieve without larger school reform, so they turned much of their attention to school restructuring and teacher-led curricular reform. This change was reflected in the movement of CHART out of the Rockefeller Foundation's arts and humanities division and into their relatively new school reform program in 1990. CHART's primary function was as a source of funding and an organizational umbrella for a variety of localized reform and education projects. The list below gives the name of each project, the year CHART began supporting it, and the year it ceased to be a CHART project. Common characteristics of all the CHART sites included localized, teacher-driven curricula, a focus on average students in urban or rural environments, and the expansion of multicultural and international education. Collaborations with other local institutions, such as museums, universities, and businesses, also formed a major element of many CHART projects. Collaboration between projects and among educators across the country was an essential element as well, as evidenced by the large number of conferences and institutes that CHART leaders attended or helped to run, including frequent meetings between all of the CHART site directors. The Rockefeller Foundation gave its tenth and final grant to CHART in 1993, and CHART formally ceased to exist as an entity in early 1994. The individual CHART project sites generally continued to operate after this time, and some connection between them may have been maintained, but this collection contains very little information pertaining to the formal end of CHART and the nature and specifics of the transfer of responsibility to individual sites.

CHART Project, Location, Years with CHART Advancing Teaching and Learning in Arkansas Schools (ATLAS), Arkansas, 1988-1993 Arts PROPEL, Pittsburgh, 1988-1993 CROSSROADS, Seattle, 1985-1988 DIALOGUE, St. Paul, 1984; 1986-1988 HUMANITAS, Los Angeles, 1986-1993 Humanities Education, Research and Learning Development (HERALD), San Francisco, 1988-1993 Inhabiting Other Lives, Miami, 1989-1993 International Education Consortium (IEC), St. Louis, 1985-1993 New Mexico CURRENTS, New Mexico, 1990-1993 New York and the World, NYC, 1986-1993 Philadelphia Alliance for Teaching Humanities in the Schools (PATHS), Philadelphia, 1983-1993 Renaissance Outreach Alliance for the Detroit Area Schools (ROADS), Detroit, 1989-1993 Rural Education Alliance for Collaborative Humanities (REACH), South Carolina, 1987-1993 Scholars United for Multicultural Inquiry in Teaching (SUMMIT), Colorado, 1990-1993 Superintendent's Academy for Humanities and Arts Teaching, D.C., 1989-1993 The Connecticut Humanities Alliance, Connecticut, 1989-1993 The National Faculty's Humanities Project, Atlanta, 1984-1986

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1, Administration, contains mainly correspondence, which is separated into two categories: the director's general correspondence and correspondence with the Rockefeller Foundation. This series also contains a few folders of planning material, one report to the trustees, and a substantial amount of information from the President's Committee on Arts and Humanities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 2, Projects, includes a variety of materials about several CHART efforts, including the Africa in the U.S. Classroom initiative, the CHARTnet telecommunications network, the legacy project, and the CHART book, Fire in the Eyes of Youth. Also included are details about several CHART-funded projects, such as conferences and surveys, and a number of exploratory proposals detailing potential future CHART sites.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3, Conferences and Institutes, contains information from the large number of conferences that CHART leaders either attended or helped to plan between 1984 and 1993. Materials include agendas, handouts, and transcripts of discussions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This section contains the single box of oversized materials from the collection, which consists of three folders of photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 4, Public Relations, includes all of CHARTs public relations materials from 1987-1994. Formal information kits from several years, which were sent out to interested parties, are in this series, as well as books, newspaper clippings, and other instances of CHART appearing in the media. Also included is communication between CHART and two different public relations firms or managers, first M. Booth and Associates and later Lenore Greenberg.
